div.p: Plaza Mexico was once known as the Marketplace, a large grey block with lots of parking was once the city’s indoor swapmeet. With construction beginning in 2004, the outside has been remodeled after the city of Monten Alban according to it’s About Me website with statues of Pancho Villa, Benito Juarez, Angel of independence and several other Mexican Icons. They host huge celebrations for Cinco de Mayo, Dia de los Muertos, and Posadas. It is largely due to the now majority population of Latina/os living within the city. In spite of being the majority within the city, the city still excludes from being recipients of economic welfare. With being owned by Korean investors a capitalistic interest is still present in the community signifying there is an exploitation of cultural appropriation within the space. The plaza provides a celebration of cultural exchange, but at what cost?

note.p: Plaza Mexico feels like you’re walking through Mexico City, with the Angel of Independencia of Monten Alba right at entrance. One will never find this swapmeet empty on the weekends.
